summary.text:
Evaluates a JEXL expression and returns the result.
If only one argument is provided, it is expected that the first argument is a JEXL expression.
If two arguments are provided, the first argument is the context (must be an object) and the second argument is the JEXL expression.
The expression uses the default JEXL extended grammar and can't use any custom defined functions or transforms.

content.text: The result of evaluating the expression, or undefined if evaluation fails.

summary.text: Either a JEXL expression string or a context object.
Optional JEXL expression when first argument is context.
Returns the absolute value of a number.

content.text: The absolute value, or NaN if input cannot be converted to a number.

summary.text: The input number to get the absolute value of.

Checks whether the provided array has any elements that match the specified expression.
The expression must be a valid JEXL expression string, and is applied to each element of the array.
The relative context provided to the expression is an object with the properties value, index and array (the original array).

content.text: True if any element matches the expression, false otherwise or if input is not an array.

summary.text: The input array to test.
The JEXL expression to test against each element.
Appends elements to an array.

content.text: A new array with all inputs flattened and appended, or empty array if no valid input.

summary.text: The input values to append to an array.
Returns a new array with duplicate elements removed.

content.text: A new array with duplicates removed, or empty array if input is not an array.

summary.text: The input array to remove duplicates from.

Checks whether the provided array has all elements that match the specified expression.
The expression must be a valid JEXL expression string, and is applied to each element of the array.
The relative context provided to the expression is an object with the properties value, index and array (the original array).

content.text: True if all elements match the expression, false otherwise or if input is not an array.

summary.text: The input array to test.
The JEXL expression to test against each element.

Returns a new array with the elements of the input array that match the specified expression.
The expression must be a valid JEXL expression string, and is applied to each element of the array.
The relative context provided to the expression is an object with the properties value, index and array (the original array).

content.text: A new array containing only elements that match the expression, or empty array if input is not an array.

summary.text: The input array to filter.
The JEXL expression to test against each element.

Finds the first element in an array that matches the specified expression.
The expression must be a valid JEXL expression string, and is applied to each element of the array.
The relative context provided to the expression is an object with the properties value, index and array (the original array).

content.text: The first element that matches the expression, or undefined if no match found or input is not an array.

summary.text: The input array to search.
The JEXL expression to test against each element.
Finds the index of the first element in the input array that satisfies the given Jexl expression.

content.text: The index of the first matching element, or
if the input is not an array.

summary.text: The array to search through.
A Jexl expression string to evaluate for each element. The expression has access to
`value`
`index`
, and
`array`
Joins elements of an array into a string.

content.text: The joined string, or undefined if input is not an array.

summary.text: The input array to join.
The separator string to use between elements. Defaults to comma.

Returns an array containing the results of applying the expression parameter to each value in the array parameter.
The expression must be a valid JEXL expression string, which is applied to each element of the array.
The relative context provided to the expression is an object with the properties value, index and array (the original array).

content.text: A new array with transformed elements, or undefined if input is not an array.

summary.text: The input array to transform.
The JEXL expression to apply to each element.
Returns a sub-array from start index to end index.

content.text: The sub-array from start to end, or empty array if input is not an array.

summary.text: The input array.
The starting index (inclusive).
The ending index (exclusive). If not provided, slices to the end of the array.

Returns an aggregated value derived from applying the function parameter successively to each value in array in combination with the result of the previous application of the function.
The expression must be a valid JEXL expression string, and behaves like an infix operator between each value within the array.
The relative context provided to the expression is an object with the properties accumulator, value, index and array (the original array).

content.text: The final accumulated value, or undefined if input is not an array.

summary.text: The input array to reduce.
The JEXL expression to apply for each reduction step.
The initial value for the accumulator.
Reverses the elements of an array.

content.text: A new array with elements in reverse order, or empty array if no valid input.

summary.text: The input values to reverse.
Shuffles the elements of an array randomly.

content.text: The same array with elements randomly shuffled, or empty array if input is not an array.

summary.text: The input array to shuffle.
Sorts the elements of an array.

content.text: A new sorted array, or empty array if input is not an array.

summary.text: The input array to sort.
Optional JEXL expression to determine sort value for objects.
Optional flag to sort in descending order.
Creates a new object based on key-value pairs or string keys.

content.text: A new object created from the input, or empty object if input is invalid.

summary.text: The input string key or array of key-value pairs.
Optional default value for string keys or when array elements are strings.
Calculates the average of an array of numbers.

content.text: The average value, or NaN if input is not an array.

summary.text: The input array of numbers or individual number arguments.
Decodes a Base64 encoded string.

content.text: The decoded string, or empty string if input is not a string.

summary.text: The Base64 encoded string to decode.
Encodes a string to Base64.

content.text: The Base64 encoded string, or empty string if input is not a string or encoding fails.

summary.text: The input string to encode.
Converts the input string to camel case.

content.text: The camel case string, or empty string if input is not a string.

summary.text: The input string to convert to camel case.
Rounds a number up to the nearest integer.

content.text: The rounded up integer, or NaN if input cannot be converted to a number.

summary.text: The input number to round up.
Checks if the input string or array contains the specified value.

content.text:
```ts
contains("hello world", "world") // true
"foo-bar"|contains("bar") // true
contains([1, 2, 3], 2) // true
```
True if the input contains the search value, false otherwise.

summary.text: The input string or array to search in.
The value to search for.
Adds a time range to a date and time in the ISO 8601 format.

content.text: The new date and time as an ISO 8601 string.

summary.text: The input date and time string in ISO 8601 format.
The time unit to add ("day", "hour", "minute", "second", "month", "year", etc.).
The amount to add (can be negative to subtract).
Converts a date and time to a provided format.

content.text: The date and time in the specified format.

summary.text: The input date and time, either as a string or number.
The format to convert the date and time to.
Parses the date and time in the ISO 8601 format and returns the number of milliseconds since the Unix epoch.

content.text: The timestamp in milliseconds since Unix epoch.

summary.text: The date and time string to parse.
Checks if the input string ends with the specified substring.

content.text:
```ts
endsWith("hello world", "world") // true
"foo-bar"|endsWith("bar") // true
endsWith("test", "xyz") // false
```
True if the input ends with the search string, false otherwise.

summary.text: The input string to check.
The substring to search for at the end.
Rounds a number down to the nearest integer.

content.text: The rounded down integer, or NaN if input cannot be converted to a number.

summary.text: The input number to round down.
Formats a number as a string in the specified base.

content.text: The number formatted in the specified base, or empty string if input cannot be converted to a number.

summary.text: The input number to format.
The numeric base to convert to (2-36).
Formats a number as an integer with zero padding.

content.text: The zero-padded integer string, or empty string if input cannot be converted to a number.

summary.text: The input number to format.
The format string indicating the minimum number of digits.
Formats a number to a decimal representation as specified by the format string.

content.text: The formatted number string, or empty string if input cannot be converted to a number.

summary.text: The input number to format.
The format string specifying decimal places and grouping.
Encodes a string or object to URI component format.

content.text: The URL encoded string, or empty string if input is not a string or object.

summary.text: The input string or object to encode.
Returns the number of characters in a string, or the length of an array.

content.text: The number of characters in a string, or the length of an array.

summary.text: The input can be a string, an array, or an object.
Converts the input string to lowercase.
The input to convert to lowercase. Non-string inputs are converted to JSON string first.
Returns a new array with elements transformed by extracting a specific field.

content.text: A new array with extracted field values, or empty array if input is not an array.

summary.text: The input array of objects to extract fields from.
The field name to extract from each object.
Finds the maximum value in an array of numbers.

content.text: The maximum value, or NaN if input is not an array.

summary.text: The input array of numbers or individual number arguments.
Returns the current date and time in milliseconds since the Unix epoch.
Finds the minimum value in an array of numbers.

content.text: The minimum value, or NaN if input is not an array.

summary.text: The input array of numbers or individual number arguments.
Returns the logical NOT of the input.

content.text:
```ts
not(true) // false
false|not // true
not(0) // true
not("") // true
```
The logical NOT of the input converted to boolean.

summary.text: The input to apply logical NOT to.
Returns the current date and time in the ISO 8601 format.

content.text: The current date and time as an ISO 8601 string.

summary.text: Returns an array of key-value pairs from the input object.

content.text: An array of [key, value] pairs, or undefined if input is not an object.

summary.text: The input object to get entries from.
Returns the keys of an object as an array.

content.text: An array of object keys, or undefined if input is not an object.

summary.text: The input object to get keys from.
Returns a new object with the properties of the input objects merged together.

content.text: A new object with all properties merged together.

summary.text: The input objects to merge.
Returns the values of an object as an array.

content.text: An array of object values, or undefined if input is not an object.

summary.text: The input object to get values from.
Pads the input string to the specified width.
The input to pad. Non-string inputs are converted to JSON string first.
The target width. Positive values pad to the right, negative values pad to the left.
The character to use for padding. Defaults to space.
Parses a string and returns an integer.

content.text: The integer value, or NaN if parsing fails.

summary.text: The input to parse as an integer.
Converts the input string to pascal case.

content.text: The pascal case string, or empty string if input is not a string.

summary.text: The input string to convert to pascal case.
Returns the value of a number raised to a power.

content.text: The result of base raised to the exponent, or NaN if input cannot be converted to a number.

summary.text: The base number.
The exponent to raise the base to. Defaults to 2.
Generates a random number between 0 (inclusive) and 1 (exclusive).

content.text: A random floating-point number between 0 and 1.

summary.text: Replaces occurrences of a specified string with a replacement string.

content.text:
```ts
replace("foo-bar-baz", "-", "_") // "foo_bar_baz"
"hello world"|replace("world", "there") // "hello there"
replace("test test test", "test", "demo") // "demo demo demo"
```
The string with replacements made, or undefined if input is not a string.

summary.text: The input string to perform replacements on.
The string to search for and replace.
The string to replace matches with. Defaults to empty string.
Rounds a number to the nearest integer or to specified decimal places.

content.text: The rounded number, or NaN if input cannot be converted to a number.

summary.text: The input number to round.
Optional number of decimal places to round to.
Splits the input string into an array of substrings.

content.text: An array of substrings, or empty array if input is not a string.

summary.text: The input string to split.
The separator string to split on.
Returns the square root of a number.

content.text: The square root of the input, or NaN if input cannot be converted to a number.

summary.text: The input number to get the square root of.
Checks if the input string starts with the specified substring.

content.text:
```ts
startsWith("hello world", "hello") // true
"foo-bar"|startsWith("foo") // true
startsWith("test", "xyz") // false
```
True if the input starts with the search string, false otherwise.

summary.text: The input string to check.
The substring to search for at the beginning.
Gets a substring of a string.

The length of the substring.
Returns the substring after the first occurrence of the character sequence chars in str.

Returns the substring before the first occurrence of the character sequence chars in str.

content.text: The substring before the first occurrence of the character sequence chars in str.

summary.text: The input string.
The character sequence to search for.
Calculates the sum of an array of numbers.

content.text: The sum of all numbers, or NaN if input is not an array.

summary.text: The input array of numbers or individual number arguments.
Evaluates a list of predicates and returns the first result expression whose predicate is satisfied.

content.text:
```ts
switch(expression, case1, result1, case2, result2, ..., default)
```
The result of the first case whose predicate is satisfied, or the default value if no case is satisfied.

summary.text: The arguments array where the first element is the expression to evaluate, followed by pairs of case and result, and optionally a default value.
Converts the input to a boolean.

content.text:
```ts
toBoolean("true") // true
"false"|toBoolean // false
toBoolean(1) // true
toBoolean(0) // false
```
The boolean value, or undefined for ambiguous string values.

Parses the number of milliseconds since the Unix epoch or parses a string (with or without specified format) and returns the date and time in the ISO 8601 format.

Optional format string for parsing date strings.

If the string is not valid JSON.

If true, the output will be pretty-printed.

readme.text:
# Jexl Extended Grammar

This package includes an extended grammar for the [Jexl expression parser and evaluator](https://github.com/TomFrost/Jexl) by TomFrost.

 **[Complete Documentation](https://docs.konnektr.io/docs/jexl)** |  **[Try the Playground](https://jexl-playground.konnektr.io/)**

## Features

-  **80+ Built-in Functions** - String manipulation, math, arrays, objects, dates, and more
-  **Monaco Editor Support** - Syntax highlighting, IntelliSense, and hover documentation  
-  **TypeScript Support** - Full type definitions included
-  **Modular** - Use the entire library or import individual functions
-  **Interactive Playground** - Try expressions online at [jexl-playground.konnektr.io](https://jexl-playground.konnektr.io/)

## Installation

## Monaco Editor Integration

Get a rich IDE experience for JEXL expressions:

)

It is also possible to use the extended grammar in the original Jexl library by importing parts of the grammar you need and adding it to the Jexl instance.

## Other Language Implementations

This extended grammar is also available in other programming languages:

- **C#**: [JexlNet](https://github.com/nikoraes/JexlNet) - A C# implementation of JEXL with extended grammar support
- **Python**: [pyjexl-extended](https://github.com/nikoraes/pyjexl-extended) - Python implementation with extended functions and transforms

## Related Projects

- [Jexl](https://github.com/TomFrost/Jexl) - The original JavaScript implementation of JEXL that this library extends
- [jexl-rs](https://github.com/mozilla/jexl-rs) - A Rust-based JEXL parser and evaluator
- [PyJEXL](https://github.com/mozilla/pyjexl) - Mozilla's Python-based JEXL parser and evaluator
